item.name: Advanced Heroquest
item.comment: I am a big fan of the original HeroQuest. This game did not hold up. The game had added complexity and lost a lot of what made the original HeroQuest great. The biggest failing of this game in my eyes, however, is the random dungeon generation feature. As appealing as this might be to gamers who wish to run through this game by themselves, it can make taking a party through a dungeon a tedious affair, never knowing wether you will find the mission critical room in a few minutes or a few hours.

item.name: Battle Line
item.comment: Very addictive fun card game. Definately recommended.

item.name: BattleTech
item.comment: Very involved miniatures game from the 80's, soon to be forgotten I fear. Fun, but lengthy.

item.name: BattleTech Science Fiction Combat Book Game
item.comment: interesting idea, but not very fun.

item.name: Gears of War: The Board Game
HeroClix
item.comment: This game has almost no tactics what so ever. Due to the fact that the tactics of movement are reduced to the mind numbing dichotomy of "close in quick and punch" or "stay away and range attack', the ultimate resolution to any game ends up with a cluster of figures and a half hour of die rolling. The only real strategy the game provides lies in building your "team." Admittedly, there are occasions where combining the heroes special abilities can make for powerful attacks and defenses. But because those abilities come and go, the chances that you can use the combination you've designed for are rare if at all. However, the little figures are neat and the collectability aspect I'm sure is appealing to many. But the game itself leaves me incredibly flat. The comics I admire the most contain heroes that display characteristics such as intelligence and chess like tactics and those traits aren't represented here. I will stick to reading comics rather than trying to play them.
